caption:
This photograph captures a scene of industrial activity set in a rugged and remote landscape. In the foreground, there are several construction workers, each dressed in heavy-duty clothing, engaged in what appears to be a work discussion or instructing each other around a lit area, possibly for night work.

The area is strewn with construction machinery and equipment, signaling a significant project, possibly related to resource extraction or infrastructure development. Visible are cranes, trucks, and other heavy machinery, a typical set-up for large-scale construction or engineering projects.

The background features an expansive water body, likely a lake or wide river, surrounded by dramatic mountainous terrain under an overcast sky. The mountains are dimly lit, suggesting either dawn or dusk, adding a moody atmosphere to the scene. The waterbody reflects some lights, indicating it might be twilight time or an overcast day.

Overall, the image depicts a blend of human enterprise and raw natural beauty, highlighting the contrast between industrial activity and the untouched wilderness surrounding it. The setting is serene yet bustling with human activity, a snapshot of the intersection between nature and development.
title: In October 1972, a pipeline of the Texas-New Mexico Pipeline Company burst, releasing 285,000 gallons of crude oil into the San Juan River. The oil flowed 200 miles downstream before being temporarily contained by a log boom near the point where the river enters Lake Powell. This view shows dragline scooping oil-laden debris from the water. Clean-up crews working around the clock were hampered by almost constant rain.
